Recent Literature of the Anglophone World
Didactic explanation of the project

Recent Literature in the History of the Anglophone World is a digital learning project designed for students in 4º ESO with an approximate B1 level of English. The project focuses on modern and contemporary literature written in English, mainly from the 20th and 21st centuries, and explores how literary texts reflect social, cultural and personal issues in English-speaking countries.

Throughout the project, students will work with adapted literary texts, images, videos and interactive activities that help them understand literature as a form of communication and cultural expression. The contents include topics that are close to teenagers’ interests, such as Young Adult literature, dystopian worlds, identity, diversity and film adaptations of books.

The project is created using eXeLearning and combines interactive and non-interactive activities to develop the four language skills: reading, writing, listening and speaking. Students are encouraged to express opinions, reflect on texts and relate literature to their own experiences. The final aim is not only to improve language competence, but also to promote reading for pleasure in English and to develop critical thinking.
Text and Tasks
Didactic Objectives

By the end of this project, students will be able to:

  • Understand the main characteristics of recent
  • Anglophone literature.
  • Read and understand adapted literary texts in English.
  • Identify themes such as identity, society, inequality and personal growth.
  • Use specific vocabulary related to literature and culture.
  • Express personal opinions about books and characters in simple English.
  • Develop interest and motivation towards reading in a foreign language.
Text and Tasks
Previous Knowledge

Before starting the project, students are expected to:

  • Know basic information about English-speaking countries.
  • Understand short and simple narrative texts in English.
  • Recognise basic literary concepts such as author, book, story and character.
  • Have experience watching films or series in English.
  • Be familiar with reading short texts in the classroom.
Text and Tasks

Modern Anglophone literature refers to literary works written in English from the 20th century to the present day. These texts are produced in different English-speaking countries, such as the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada, Australia and others. Modern writers often focus on real-life problems, personal experiences and social changes.

Unlike classical literature, modern literature uses simpler language and more realistic characters. Many stories deal with topics such as identity, family, friendship, racism, gender equality, war or technology. Literature becomes a way for writers to express opinions and to help readers understand the world around them.

English has become a global language, and this is why Anglophone literature is so diverse. Writers from different cultures use English to tell their stories, giving readers multiple perspectives. Today, books are also connected to other media, such as films, series and digital platforms, making literature more accessible to young readers.

Contemporary British Literature

Contemporary British literature includes novels and stories written in the United Kingdom from the late 20th century to today. Many British writers focus on realistic situations and social issues that affect modern society. Their stories often show everyday life, especially the lives of young people, families and communities.

Common themes in British literature are identity, class differences, immigration, friendship and growing up. Writers use literature to talk about how society is changing and how people feel about these changes. The language is usually clear and direct, which makes these texts easier to understand for modern readers.

One of the most famous British writers is J.K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter series. Although the story includes magic, it also talks about friendship, courage and personal growth, which are very important themes in modern literature.

A fascinating curiosity about J.K. Rowling’s writing process is that she spent five years just planning and world-building before she even finished the first chapter of Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone.

During those years, she created an immense amount of "backstage" material that never made it into the books, but ensured the world felt consistent.
Modern American Literature
Reading time
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.
  3. Think about activities where the perceived benefit of doing the activity outweighs the time and effort it will take to complete the activity.
Reading Activity
Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read

Modern American literature reflects the diversity of the United States. Writers often tell stories about identity, race, family and personal dreams. Many novels focus on young people who are trying to understand who they are and where they belong. These stories help readers connect literature with real life.
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.

1. What is the main idea of the text?
  2. Write two themes mentioned in the text.
  3. Find one word related to feelings.
  4. Do you think these stories are realistic? Why?
  5. Write one sentence giving your opinion about the text.
Use feedback to provide a summary of the points covered in the reading, or as a starting point for further analysis of the reading by posing a question or providing a statement to begin a debate.

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

Young Adult (YA) Literature

Young Adult literature, often called YA literature, is written for teenagers and young adults. The main characters are usually young people who face problems similar to those of real teenagers. These books are very popular because readers can easily identify with the characters.

YA novels often deal with themes such as friendship, love, family problems, bullying, mental health and self-discovery. The language is simple and direct, and the stories are fast-paced and emotional. Many YA books have been adapted into films, which has increased their popularity.

Examples of famous YA books include The Hunger Games, The Fault in Our Stars and Divergent.

Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

1. Do you like reading YA books? Why or why not?
  2. What problems do teenagers face today?
  3. Do you prefer books or films? Explain your answer.
  4. Why do you think YA literature is so popular?
  5. Would you recommend a YA book to a friend?
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
Model example

I like reading Young Adult books because the characters are usually teenagers and their problems feel real. Today, many teenagers face problems such as stress, bullying, family difficulties and pressure from social media. I prefer books to films because books explain characters’ feelings in more detail. YA literature is very popular because young people can identify with the characters and the stories are easy to understand and emotional. I would recommend a YA book to a friend because these books are interesting and help us feel understood.

Dystopian Fiction

Dystopian fiction describes imaginary societies where life is difficult or unfair. These stories are often set in the future and show worlds controlled by governments, technology or strict rules. Writers use dystopian fiction to criticise real problems in society.

Common themes in dystopian novels include lack of freedom, inequality, surveillance and rebellion. The main characters are usually young people who question the system and try to change it. These stories make readers think about the consequences of social and political decisions.

Popular dystopian novels include The Hunger Games and Divergent.

Text and Tasks
Women Writers in the Anglophone World
Women importance

Women writers have played an important role in modern Anglophone literature. Many of them write about gender equality, identity, family and personal freedom. Their stories often give voice to experiences that were ignored in the past.

Modern women writers create strong characters and realistic situations. Through literature, they express opinions and fight stereotypes. Reading their works helps students understand different perspectives and social changes.
Text and Tasks
Real situation
University of Auckland
Provide relevant feedback on the situation.

A case study is a device that provides learners with a simulation that has an educational basis. It takes a situation, generally based in reality, and asks learners to demonstrate or describe what action they would take to complete a task or resolve a situation. The case study allows learners apply their own knowledge and experience to completing the tasks assigned. when designing a case study consider the following:
  • What educational points are conveyed in the story
  • What preparation will the learners need to do prior to working on the case study
  • Where the case study fits into the rest of the course
  • How the learners will interact with the materials and each other e.g. if run in a classroom situation can teams be setup to work on different aspects of the case and if so how are ideas feed back to the class
Describe the activity tasks relevant to the case story provided. These could be in the form of questions or instructions for activity which may lead the learner to resolving a dilemma presented.

Create the case story. A good case is one that describes a controversy or sets the scene by describing the characters involved and the situation. It should also allow for some action to be taken in order to gain resolution of the situation.
Case Study
C:\Program Files (x86)\exe\images\empty.gif

1. Choose one female author.
  2. Write the title of one of her books.
  3. Explain what the book is about.
  4. Say why the class should read it.
  5. Share your personal opinion.
Show model answer

Female Author: Margaret Atwood Book Title: The Handmaid’s Tale

What the book is about: The story is set in a near-future New England, in a totalitarian state called Gilead. Due to a fertility crisis, the government treats women as property of the state. The narrator, Offred, is a "Handmaid" whose only purpose is to bear children for elite couples. The novel follows her daily life, her memories of the "time before," and her quiet attempts to maintain her identity in a world that tries to erase it.

Why the class should read it: Our class should read this book because it is a masterpiece of speculative fiction. It provides a deep look at how language, power, and history can be manipulated by those in control. It encourages intense classroom debates about human rights, politics, and the importance of individual freedom. Furthermore, Atwood’s writing style is poetic yet accessible, making it an excellent tool for analyzing literary devices like symbolism and motifs.

Personal Opinion: In my opinion, The Handmaid’s Tale is a chilling but necessary read. What I find most impressive is that Atwood famously stated she didn't put anything in the book that hadn't already happened somewhere in history. This makes the "dystopia" feel terrifyingly real. It isn't just a story; it’s a mirror that asks us to reflect on our own society and how we protect our values.

Literature and Film Adapatations

Many books are adapted into films and series. Film adaptations help stories reach a wider audience and make literature more popular among young people. However, films often change details from the original book.

Books usually provide more information about characters and feelings, while films focus on images and action. Comparing books and films helps students develop critical thinking skills.

DropDown exercises are texts or sentences where students must select the correct words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Choose words in the text that are key to understanding the concepts. These will probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge
If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

Write a short review (80–100 words) of a book or story you like.
Include:

  1. Title and author
  2. Type of book
  3. Short summary
  4. Your opinion
  5. Recommendation
